name: charter
content:
charter

noun
 
 
/ˈtʃɑːtə(r)/
 
/ˈtʃɑːrtər/
jump to other results
  1.  
    [countable] a written statement describing the rights that a particular group of people should have
    • the European Social Charter of workers’ rights
    • a rail passenger’s charter
    • a charter of rights for people with disabilities
    Extra Examples
    • a national charter for the protection of animals
    • He fought for a social charter of workers' rights.
    • Minority rights are protected by the UN charter.
    • A commission was appointed to draw up a charter to regulate political life.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • draft
    • founding
    • social
    • …
    verb + charter
    • draft
    • draw up
    • sign
    • …
    preposition
    • charter for
    • charter of
    See full entry
  2.  
    [countable] a written statement of the principles and aims of an organization synonym constitution
    • the United Nations Charter
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • draft
    • founding
    • social
    • …
    verb + charter
    • draft
    • draw up
    • sign
    • …
    preposition
    • charter for
    • charter of
    See full entry
  3.  
    [countable] an official document stating that a government or political leader allows a new organization, town or university to be established and gives it particular rights
    • The Royal College received its charter as a university in 1967.
    • Certain towns were allowed to hold weekly markets, by royal charter.
    Extra Examples
    • The BBC's charter was due to be renewed.
    • The university received its Royal Charter in 1946.
    • They were given this right by royal charter.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • royal
    • city
    • corporate
    • …
    verb + charter
    • give somebody/​something
    • grant somebody/​something
    • issue
    • …
    preposition
    • by charter
    See full entry
  4. [singular] charter (for something) (British English) a law or policy that seems likely to help people do something bad
    • The new law will be a charter for unscrupulous financial advisers.
    • a blackmailer’s charter
  5. [uncountable] the hiring of a plane, boat, etc.
    • a yacht available for charter
    Topics Transport by waterc2, Transport by airc2
    6. Word OriginMiddle English: from Old French chartre, from Latin chartula, diminutive of charta ‘paper’from Greek khartēs ‘papyrus leaf’.
See charter in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee charter in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: charter
content:
charter

verb
 
/ˈtʃɑːtə(r)/
 
/ˈtʃɑːrtər/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they charter
 
/ˈtʃɑːtə(r)/
 
/ˈtʃɑːrtər/
he / she / it charters
 
/ˈtʃɑːtəz/
 
/ˈtʃɑːrtərz/
past simple chartered
 
/ˈtʃɑːtəd/
 
/ˈtʃɑːrtərd/
past participle chartered
 
/ˈtʃɑːtəd/
 
/ˈtʃɑːrtərd/
-ing form chartering
 
/ˈtʃɑːtərɪŋ/
 
/ˈtʃɑːrtərɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. charter something to hire a plane, boat, etc. for your own use
    • They flew to Athens and then chartered a boat to the island.
    Wordfinder
    • cabin crew
    • charter
    • flight path
    • in-flight
    • land
    • long-haul
    • plane
    • refuel
    • take-off
    • travel
    Extra Examples
    • Special trains were chartered to take them to the festival.
    • The club chartered a special flight from Manchester to Turin.
    • The oil companies use both owned and chartered ships.
    Topics Transport by waterc2, Transport by airc2
  2. [usually passive] charter something to state officially that a new organization, town or university has been established and has special rights
    3. Word OriginMiddle English: from Old French chartre, from Latin chartula, diminutive of charta ‘paper’from Greek khartēs ‘papyrus leaf’.
See charter in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: royal charter
content:
royal charter

noun
 
/ˌrɔɪəl ˈtʃɑːtə(r)/
 
/ˌrɔɪəl ˈtʃɑːrtər/
jump to other results
  1. an award given by the Queen or King on the advice of the Privy Council to certain organizations or institutions which are recognized as the leading authorities in their field. Organizations with royal charters include the BBC, the British Academy and some British universities.
Check pronunciation: royal charter

name: charter flight
content:
charter flight

noun
 
/ˈtʃɑːtə flaɪt/
 
/ˈtʃɑːrtər flaɪt/
jump to other results
  1. a flight in an aircraft in which all the seats are paid for by a travel company and then sold to their customers compare scheduled flightTopics Transport by airc2
See charter flight in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: charter flight

name: charter member
content:
charter member

noun
 
/ˌtʃɑːtə ˈmembə(r)/
 
/ˌtʃɑːrtər ˈmembər/
(also founding member)
(both North American English)
(British English founder member)
jump to other results
  1. one of the first members of a society, an organization, etc., especially one who helped start it
See charter member in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: charter member

name: charter school
content:
charter school

 
/ˈtʃɑːtə skuːl/
 
/ˈtʃɑːrtər skuːl/
jump to other results
  1. (in the US) a school that has been established by teachers, parents or community groups, but receives public funds, and places special emphasis on a particular subject or teaching method
    • Both of her children attend a performing arts charter school.
    • a Chinese immersion charter school
Check pronunciation: charter school

name: the Atlantic Charter
content:
the Atlantic Charter

 
/ði ətˌlæntɪk ˈtʃɑːtə(r)/
 
/ði əˌtlæntɪk ˈtʃɑːrtər/
jump to other results
  1. an agreement signed by Winston Churchill, the British Prime Minister, and Franklin D Roosevelt, the US President, in 1941 about the rights of nations and international relations. Its main purpose was to condemn the actions of Germany. In 1942 statements of the Atlantic Charter became part of the Declaration of the United Nations. see also Second World War
Check pronunciation: the Atlantic Charter

name: the Citizen's Charter
content:
the Citizen's Charter

 
/ðə ˌsɪtɪznz ˈtʃɑːtə(r)/
 
/ðə ˌsɪtɪznz ˈtʃɑːrtər/
jump to other results
  1. a social programme introduced by the British Prime Minister John Major in 1991. Its aim was to improve the standard of public services and to make government departments explain their actions more clearly to the public. It was replaced by a different scheme called the Big Society in 2010.
Check pronunciation: the Citizen's Charter

name: the Patient's Charter
content:
the Patient's Charter

 
/ðə ˌpeɪʃnts ˈtʃɑːtə(r)/
 
/ðə ˌpeɪʃnts ˈtʃɑːrtər/
jump to other results
  1. a statement of the rights of people who use the National Health Service in Britain. It was published by the government in 1992 and replaced by the NHS Constitution for England in 2011. compare Citizen's Charter
Check pronunciation: the Patient's Charter

name: the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
content:
the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

noun
 
/ðə kəˌneɪdiən ˌtʃɑːtər əv ˌraɪts ən ˈfriːdəmz/
 
/ðə kəˌneɪdiən ˌtʃɑːrtər əv ˌraɪts ən ˈfriːdəmz/
(also the Charter)
[singular] (Canadian English)
jump to other results
  1. an official document that is part of Canada's constitution (= its set of basic laws), and that guarantees basic political, legal and language rights, as well as the rights of AboriginalsTopics Law and justicec2
See the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
